awd_titl_txt: EAGER/GOALI: 3D Printing of Nanostructured Battery Electrodes
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) and Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) funding will explore the feasibility of combining 3D printing and nanoscale fiber electrospinning to enable improved battery electrodes. Fusion Deposition Modeling (FDM) is a type of 3D printing that creates a three-dimensional object by melting, extruding and depositing a thermoplastic polymer filament in a pre-determined path layer-by-layer.  One limitation of the FDM process is the coarse feature size (50-400 microns). Electrospinning is a unique nanomaterial fabrication technique that continuously produces nanoscale fibers but with very limited control over their exact placement. The electrospinning process is inherently compatible with roll-to-roll processing and potentially compatible with 3D printing. This research will explore the feasibility of marrying the two concepts of 3D printing and electrospinning, creating a new and potentially impactful type of 3D nanoprinting. The team will use a combination of experiments and computational simulations to test the effect of electric field on the spatial deposition of nanofibers. The discovery could impact manufacturing capabilities of high performance materials for applications in energy, healthcare and national security. One graduate and several undergraduate students will be supported to conduct academic and industrial research. 

The specific aim of this project is to build a dual-nozzle 3D electrospinning platform to enable simultaneous nano-extrusion of polymeric conductive host and sulfur-rich copolymer active material in a pre-defined path. The ultimate aim is to print 3D cathodes for Lithium-Sulfur batteries that exhibit dimensional accuracy at multiple length scales. While the overlapping extrusion of multiple functional materials will allow nanoscale contact for enhanced electrochemical performance (reaction kinetics, conductivity, and active material utilization), the design freedom of 3D printing will enable precise x-y-z control over nanofiber positioning for tailoring bulk macroscale properties such as porosity and volumetric density - important considerations for commercial applications. Finite element-based COMSOL simulations will be used to predict the electric potential distribution as a function of various relevant process/equipment parameters. The simulations will be integrated with experiments with the aim to establish correlations between equipment/process parameters, electric field distribution, fiber diameter and spatial deposition control. The final aim of the research will be to study the fundamental electrochemical behavior, battery assembly, battery testing and post mortem material and reactant/product characterization in collaboration with the industrial partner.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Through this EAGER project, we investigated the feasibility of combining 3D printing and nanoscale fiber electrospinning to enable improved battery electrodes. Fusion Deposition Modeling (FDM) is a type of 3D printing that creates a three-dimensional object by melting, extruding and depositing a thermoplastic polymer filament in a pre-determined path layer-by-layer. One limitation of the FDM process is the coarse feature size (50-400 microns). Electrospinning is a unique nanomaterial fabrication technique that continuously produces nanoscale fibers but with very limited control over their exact placement. The electrospinning process is inherently compatible with roll-to-roll processing and potentially compatible with 3D printing. With help from experiments and computational simulations, we demonstrated the proof of concept of marrying the two concepts of 3D printing and electrospinning, creating a new and potentially impactful type of 3D nanoprinting.

This ultimate aim is to develop a continuous roll to roll nanomanufacturing technique that will result in freestanding mats of nanofibers with controlled architecture and multifunctionalities. This work directly ties into PI's ongoing work in the field of next generation energy devices. Such a nanofiber mat with at least a “mm” level z-thickness and well-defined fiber layout will enable high material loading, tunable bulk porosity, and optimized mechanical properties necessary for commercial battery or supercapacitor electrodes.

 

Intellectual Merit

This EAGER project has resulted in 3 peer-reviewed journal articles (listed below) and two conference presentations.

  • Rafie, Ayda; Singh, Arvinder; Kalra, Vibha. (2021). Synergistic effect of sulfur-rich copolymer/S8 and carbon host porosity in Li-S batteries.  Electrochimica Acta. 365.
  • Pereira, Rhyz; Sarode, Krishna Kumar; Rafie, Ayda; Fafarman, Aaron; Kalra, Vibha. (2023). In-Operando FTIR Study on the Redox Behavior of Sulfurized Polyacrylonitrile as Cathode Material for Li–S Batteries.  The Journal of Physical Chemistry C.
  • Rafie, Ayda; Kim, Jin Won; Sarode, Krishna K.; Kalra, Vibha. (2022). A review on the use of carbonate-based electrolytes in Li-S batteries: A comprehensive approach enabling solid-solid direct conversion reaction.  Energy Storage Materials. 50, 197.

 

Summary of Results

As part of this project, we investigated two key techniques to limit the whipping instability during electrospinning. The whipping motion is known to generate random nanofiber deposition causing lack of spatial control of material/nanofiber deposition. In the first technique, we employed near-field electrospinning where the working distance between the nozzle and the collector was kept short to prevent the onset of the whipping instability. In the second technique, which was a key focus of this work, we worked on an apparatus design to introduce a secondary electrode in the fluid path to focus the electric field for better geometric control. We developed a computational scheme to model and simulate the electrostatic field between the syringe needle, the auxiliary electrode, and the collector plate to elucidate nanofiber deposition behavior and guide experiments. Following the computational approach, we took a deep dive into experimental investigation and analysis. Specifically, the first sets of experiments with polyacrylonitrile and polyvinyl pyrrolidone focused on developing an understanding of the auxiliary electrode and the process parameters. The next set of experiments focused on creating a stable point of fiber deposition. The most important aspect of the project was creating circular and linear patterns using the appropriate parameters and electrical/mechanical setup.

 

Broader Impact

This project involved three graduate students from the PI’s research group. It provided all the students involved with inter-disciplinary experience in nanomaterials and alternate energy along with an opportunity to enhance their presentation and technical writing skills via several conference and group meeting presentations and paper and report writing. This GOALI project also enabled the students to gain industry perspective in advanced manufacturing and batteries. Additionally, this work provided direct research experience to three undergraduate students. Unlike classroom learning, such an experience encouraged the undergraduate students to think out of the box, come up with innovative solutions and better understand their future interests. For example, the experience gained by one of the undergraduate students in our lab through this project facilitated him to obtain employment in the research department of a battery company after his graduation.

The long-term objective of this project is to fabricate and study novel cathodes for lithium-sulfur batteries. If successful. these batteries will provide twice the energy density at device level compared to state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries. Higher energy density will facilitate reduction of weight and cost of these batteries, which is necessary to truly replace internal combustion engines in the transportation sector that currently accounts for 2/3rd of United States' consumption of petroleum and is responsible of 60% of carbon monoxide emissions into the environment.  In summary, this work aims at providing a green energy source particularly for transportation application and at reducing our dependency on oil and is therefore expected to have a direct impact on society.

 


Last Modified: 03/03/2024
Modified by: Vibha Kalra

With help from experiments and computational simulations, we demonstrated the proof of concept of marrying the two concepts of 3D printing and electrospinning, creating a new and potentially impactful type of 3D nanoprinting.


This ultimate aim is to develop a continuous roll to roll nanomanufacturing technique that will result in freestanding mats of nanofibers with controlled architecture and multifunctionalities. This work directly ties into PI's ongoing work in the field of next generation energy devices. Such a nanofiber mat with at least a mm level z-thickness and well-defined fiber layout will enable high material loading, tunable bulk porosity, and optimized mechanical properties necessary for commercial battery or supercapacitor electrodes.

Rafie, Ayda; Singh, Arvinder; Kalra, Vibha.(2021).Synergistic effect of sulfur-rich copolymer/S8 and carbon host porosity in Li-S batteries.Electrochimica Acta.365.

The next set of experiments focused on creating a stable point of fiber deposition. The most important aspect of the project was creating circular and linear patterns using the appropriate parameters and electrical/mechanical setup.

It provided all the students involved with inter-disciplinary experience in nanomaterials and alternate energy along with an opportunity to enhance their presentation and technical writing skills via several conference and group meeting presentations and paper and report writing. This GOALI project also enabled the students to gain industry perspective in advanced manufacturing and batteries.
